indicators.justification:
The Ministry of Land and Environment does not have any kind of device or data open for public access. In 2008, Mozambique adopted a National Programme of Action on Climate Change Adaptation (NAPA).

The NAPA contains information on urgent and immediate needs for building capacity to mitigate the adverse impacts of Climate Change.

In addition, Mozambique has a Pilot Climate Resilience Programme (PPCR), but the data is not available for tracking and monitoring. The Pilot Programme on Climate Resilience (PPCR) is one of the programmes under the Strategic Climate Fund (SCF) of the Climate Investment Fund (CIF).

It is designed to lead and demonstrate ways on how to integrate climate risk and resilience into policies and planning in developing countries. The PPCRs are country-led and will enable mentor countries to transform specific investment plans and programmes to address climate risks and vulnerabilities by building relevant country strategies and research.

The implementation of the PPCR at the national level, known as the Strategic Programme for Climate Resilience (SPCR), aims to generate knowledge, learning and lessons to inform the future scaling up of PPCR interventions across the country and build the resilience of the national economy as well as all sectors and communities to the risks posed by increased climate variability.

Mozambique created the Monitoring, Reporting and Verification Unit (MRV), which is part of the project management portfolio of the National Fund for Sustainable Development, within the monitoring and evaluation division.

indicators.justification:
Mozambique has no detailed land and tenure information. Since 2017, as part of the implementation of the Terra Segura (Safe Land) Programme, the Mozambican Government, with the support of the International Association for Development (World Bank Group), designed the MozLand (Safe Land) Project, whose goal is to regularise two million land rights and delimit one thousand and two hundred areas occupied by local communities in seventy-one selected districts, thus contributing to the overall goal of the Terra Segura (Safe Land) Programme.

The management, coordination, supervision, monitoring and evaluation of the Project is the responsibility of the National Fund for Sustainable Development (FNDS), under the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MADER), and the technical supervision is ensured by the National Directorate of Land and Territorial Development (DNDT), National Centre for Cartography and Remote Sensing (CENACARTA) of the Ministry of Land and Environment (MTA) and the National Directorate of Territorial Organization (DNOT) of the Ministry of State Administration and Public Function (MAEFP).

indicators.justification:
There is no clarity on how people with disabilities can benefit from the data/information that is collected/produced. Mozambique has marked steps towards building an inclusive society, where the human rights and fundamental freedoms of all people are respected with equality and without discrimination.

Under Article 11 of the Constitution of the Republic, the Mozambican State has as its objective the defence and promotion of human rights and equality of citizens before the law. In 2010, Mozambique took an important step in strengthening the protection and promotion of the rights of persons with disabilities by ratifying the 2006 UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and its Optional Protocol.

However, despite this encouraging and inclusive legal framework from a formal point of view, disability has historically been treated as a social security aspect and included in legislation of a social nature.

In Mozambique, and as happens in many parts of the world, there is a chronic and systematic exclusion and marginalization of people with disabilities from effective and full participation in social life.

indicators.justification:
Mozambique has a Law on access to information, adopted in December 2014 (1). The law has already been regulated and has some provisions that facilitate access to data. However, there is no specific law on open data.

The Law on access to information regulates the exercise of the right to information, the materialization of the constitutional principle of permanent democratic participation of citizens in public life and the guarantee of related fundamental rights (2).

The public and private entities covered by this Law have the duty to make available the information of public interest in their possession, publishing it through the various means allowed by law, which may make it increasingly accessible to the citizen, without prejudice to the exceptions expressly provided for in this Law and other applicable legislation.

The Constitution of the Republic of Mozambique stipulates that all citizens have the right to freedom of expression, freedom of the press, as well as the right to information.

indicators.justification:
There are some Civil Society Organizations working to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use. They are (1) Rural environment Observatory (Observatório do Meio Rural - OMR) and (2) Living Earth Centre (Centro Terra Viva - CTV).

OMR intends to contribute to agrarian and rural development in an integrated and interdisciplinary perspective, through research, studies and debates about policies and other agrarian and rural development issues. Contribute to the design and monitoring of agrarian and rural development policies.

The Centro Terra Viva - Estudos e Advocacia Ambiental (CTV) is a Mozambican non-governmental organization, created in 2002. It aims to promote and ensure the participation of civil society in environmental education and information, as well as the adoption and implementation of legislation about land. CTV does environmental research and advocacy.

However, we do not confirm that there is a concrete impact of these organisations on changing legislation or even land access rights, as it is the government that makes the final decisions on land policy.
